definition: What can you have against it? (idiom)/We should do this./Go for it!
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)
variant of 為|为[wei4], because of/for/to
variant of 為|为[wei2]/as (i.e. in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do
as (in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do/by (in the passive voice)

sentences.english: If you can do all that without booting up a computer, why bother?
sentences.chinese: 如果你不用启动电脑就能做到这些，何乐而不为呢？

sentences.english: So why shouldn't Google have access too?
sentences.chinese: 既然如此，谷歌何乐而不为呢？

sentences.english: If we have not lived well, then it is good that death comes and puts an end to the miserable life.
sentences.chinese: 若一路坎坷，死既来之，将这不幸带走又何乐而不为？

sentences.english: I was so embarrassed, lift a finger, what is there against it?
sentences.chinese: 我很尴尬，举手之劳，何乐而不为呢？

definition: one move, two gains (idiom); two birds with one stone
to satisfy rival demands (idiom)/to get the best of both worlds/to have it both ways/to have one's cake and eat it too
lit. one arrow, two golden eagles (idiom)/to kill two birds with one stone
see 未可厚非[wei4 ke3 hou4 fei1]
profitable to both sides/a win-win situation
to kill two birds with one stone (idiom)

particle indicating that a previously asked question is to be applied to the preceding word ("What about ...?", "And ...?")/particle for inquiring about location ("Where is ...?")/particle signaling a pause, to emphasize the preceding words and allow the listener time to take them on board ("ok?", "are you with me?")/(at the end of a declarative sentence) particle indicating continuation of a state or action/particle indicating strong affirmation
As You Like It, comedy by Shakespeare
there is no harm in/might as well
